Enhanced nitrobenzene reduction by modified biochar supported sulfidated nano zerovalent iron: Comparison of surface modification methods
Dejin Zhang a, Yang Li a, Aiwu Sun b,⁎, Siqi Tong a, Guanyong Su a, Xinbai Jiang a, Jiansheng Li a, Weiqing Han a, Xiuyun Sun a, Lianjun Wang a, Jinyou Shen a,⁎ a Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Chemical Pollution Control and Resources Reuse, School of Environmental and Biological Engineering, Nanjing University of Science and Technology, Nanjing 210094, China b Faculty of Chemical Engineering, Huaiyin Institute of Technology, Huaiyin 223001, Jiangsu Province, China
H I G H L I G H T S G R A P H I C A L A B S T R A C T
• BC was modified by H2O2, NaOH and HCl in order to enhance S-nZVI supporting. • S-nZVI@HCl-BC showed excellent NB removal and AN formation performance. • Mass ratio of S-nZVI andHCl-BCwas optimized for enhanced NB removal. • Mechanism involved in enhanced NB removal by S-nZVI@HCl-BC was proposed.

In our previous study, biochar (BC) supported sulfidated nano zerovalent iron (S-nZVI@BC) was prepared for nitrobenzene (NB) reduction. In this study, in order to further improve the reduction performance of S-nZVI@BC, BC was modified before the loading of S-nZVI through three methods: oxidant (H2O2) pretreatment, alkali (NaOH) pretreatment and acid (HCl) pretreatment. The results indicated that S-nZVI could be evenly distributed ontoHCl-BC due to increased surface area, negative surface charge and increased acidic functional groups onHClBC. At an initial concentration of 200mg L−1, NB could be completely removed by S-nZVI@HCl-BCwithin a reaction time as short as 60 min, indicating rather excellent performance of S-nZVI@HCl-BC. NB reduction performance followed the order: S-nZVI@HCl-BC N S-nZVI@NaOH-BC N S-nZVI@BC N S-nZVI@H2O2-BC. The mass ratio of S-nZVI and HCl-BC was optimized in terms of NB removal efficiency, with 3:1 being identified as the bestmass ratio. Furthermore, themechanism involved in the enhancedNB reduction by S-nZVI@HCl-BCwas proposed. This study demonstrated that S-nZVI@HCl-BC is a promising alternative for efficient NB removal from wastewater.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Nitrobenzene (NB) has been extensively used in the production of explosives, insecticides, pharmaceuticals and dyes, resulting in increasing environmental deterioration caused by NB pollution (Mu et al., 2009). NB has been classified as a priority contaminant by the United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA). The suggested maximum allowable concentrations in wastewater and drinking water are 1 mg L−1 and 17 μg L−1, respectively (Zhang and Chen, 2009). Therefore, the control of NB pollution has gained increasing attention (Dong et al., 2015). Much effort has been expended on NB removal from contaminatedwater bymethods such as adsorption (Qin andXu, 2016), advanced oxidation (Li et al., 2017b), reduction (Dong et al., 2015) and biodegradation (Cao et al., 2018). Reductive degradation, either biotic or abiotic, is more favorable than oxidative degradation due to the electron-deficient character of the nitro group in NB (Zhang et al., 2007). The primary reduction product of NB, that is, aniline (AN), is much less toxic and much more biodegradable than NB, suggesting the effectiveness of reductive degradation in terms of detoxification (Paula et al., 2015).
Recently, the potential role of sulfidated nano zerovalent iron (SnZVI) in pollutant remediation has attracted significant attention due to its larger specific surface area and higher reduction capacity than nZVI (Han and Yan, 2016). The generated iron sulfide can act as an electron transfer medium, which can efficiently transfer electrons from the nZVI core to target pollutants on its surface (Tang et al., 2016). However, the application of S-nZVI in the field of environmental remediation still poses some challenges, such as easy agglomeration, easy oxidation and extra electron loss (Zhang et al., 2018). Loading of nZVI onto support materials such as biopolymers, minerals and carbonaceous material has been widely investigated to prevent the aggregation and oxidation of nZVI (Stefaniuk et al., 2016). Thus, it can be inferred that the loading of S-nZVI particles onto these supportmaterialswill be a favorable alternative in terms of achieving better dispersion and higher reactivity. In our previous study, biochar (BC) supported S-nZVI (S-nZVI@BC) was successfully prepared through simultaneous reduction of FeSO4 by Na2S2O4 and NaBH4 onto BC (Zhang et al., 2018). The results indicated that the reduction performance of S-nZVI@BC was obviously superior to that of S-nZVI, which could be attributed to increased NB adsorption onto S-nZVI@BC, direct reduction by S-nZVI and enhanced electron transfer.
BC, which can be easily produced from cost-optimal raw biomass by pyrolysis under limited oxygen conditions, is attracting increasing attention in the field of environmental remediation (Chen et al., 2014). Nevertheless, on account of the limited porosity and functional groups, pristine BC shows poor performance in contaminant removal (Tang et al., 2018). Therefore, appropriate modification of BC is necessary to improve remediation efficiency and ensure environmental benefits (Rajapaksha et al., 2016; Liu et al., 2015). It has been reported that the adsorption capacity of methylene blue using BC modified by HNO3 could be increased to 77.4 mg g−1 as compared to 37.2 mg g−1 using BC without modification (Wang et al., 2018). NaOH-pretreated BC showed a higher chloramphenicol adsorption capacity (~2.1 mg g−1) than BCwithout pretreatment (Fan et al., 2010). Xue et al. (2012) demonstrated that the Pb2+ adsorption capacity of BC after pretreatment by H2O2was almost 20 times higher than that of rawBC. Thus, these results showed that the surface property of BC could be improved through various modifications, which ultimately affect the loading of S-nZVI. However, a comparison of different BCmodificationmethods for the loading of S-nZVI is still unavailable.
Herein, in order to improve the surface characteristics of BC for the loading of S-nZVI, different modification methods, namely oxidant pretreatment, alkali pretreatment and acid pretreatment, were investigated. The performance of modified BC supported S-nZVI was evaluated in terms of NB reduction, AN formation and electrochemical properties. In addition, the mass ratio of S-nZVI and modified BC was
optimized. The underlyingmechanism involved in enhanced NB reduction by modified BC supported S-nZVI was proposed.

sections.heading: 2. Materials and methods
sections.text:
2.1. Modification of BC
In this study, BC was prepared using rice husk as raw material following the method described by Alvarez et al. (2014). BC modification through oxidant, alkali and acid was performed adapting the procedure reported by Dong et al. (2017a). Briefly, raw BC (1.0 g) was mixed with 100 mL of 30% H2O2 solution, 1 M of NaOH, or 1 M of HCl, respectively. After stirring at room temperature for 24 h, the obtained BC particles were washed with deionized water until the pH value of the effluent was approximately 6.0. Then, the BC particles after washing were dried in a vacuum at 50 °C for 12 h. The prepared BC treated with oxidant, alkali and acid was labeled as H2O2-BC, NaOH-BC and HCl-BC, respectively.

sections.heading: 2.2. Synthesis of BC supported S-nZVI
sections.text:
Modified BC supported S-nZVI was synthesized via the method described in our previous study (Zhang et al., 2018). Briefly, 0.63 g ofmodified BC or blank BC was mixed with 8.0 g of FeSO4·7H2O in 100 mL of deionized water and the mixture was stirred for 30 min. Thereafter, 100 mL of freshly prepared solution containing 7.6 g of NaBH4 and 0.75 g of Na2S2O4was added dropwise to themixturewith vigorous stirring under a nitrogen atmosphere for another 1 h. The precipitate was collected using a magnet and washed with deionized water and deoxygenated ethanol. Thereafter, the resulting precipitate was dried in an oven at 50 °C under vacuumovernight. For all BC supported S-nZVI samples, the molar ratio of S/Fe was controlled at 0.3:1 (Song et al., 2017) and the mass ratio of S-nZVI/BC was controlled at 3:1 (Zhang et al., 2018). S-nZVI supported on blank BC, H2O2-BC, NaOH-BC and HCl-BC was labeled as S-nZVI@BC, S-nZVI@H2O2-BC, S-nZVI@NaOH-BC and SnZVI@HCl-BC, respectively. The mass ratio of S-nZVI and modified BC was further optimized in terms of NB removal and AN formation. Mass ratios of S-nZVI and modified BC varied from 0.5:1 to 7:1 but with S-nZVI dosage kept constant at 1.89 g.
2.3. NB removal by modified BC supported S-nZVI
NB removal performance of the synthesized modified BC supported S-nZVI was evaluated using 125 mL serum bottles as batch reactors. Each serum bottle was loaded with 100 mL of NB solution and 0.1 g of modified BC supported S-nZVI. Themixture was shaken on a horizontal vibrator at 200 rpm and 30 ± 1 °C in the dark. The headspace of each bottle was purged with nitrogen to eliminate the interference of oxygen. In order to evaluate the adsorption of NB onto blank BC ormodified BC, a serious of control experiments was carried out likewise but with the addition of blank BC or modified BC to the NB solution. The dosage of blank BC or modified BC was controlled at 0.025 g since the mass ratio of S-nZVI/BC was 3:1. NB solution containing 200 mg L−1 of NB prepared by dissolving 0.17mL of NB directly into 1000mL of deionized water but without the addition of any other chemicals.

sections.heading: 2.4. Analytical methods
sections.text:
Themorphologies ofmodified BC andmodified BC supported S-nZVI were characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Quant 250FEG, FEI, USA). Surface functional groups on BC were analyzed using Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR, Nicolet IS10, Thermo Scientific, USA) over a wavenumber range from 400 to 4000 cm−1. The specific surface area of BC was analyzed by a Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) analyzer (ASAP 3020, Micromeritics, USA). Zeta potential of BC wasmeasured using a Zeta potential analyzer
(ZS90, Malvern, UK). An X-ray diffractometer (XRD, D8 Advance, Bruker-AXS, Germany) was used to analyze the chemical composition of modified BC and modified BC supported S-nZVI. Electrochemical analysis was performed according to Li et al. (2016) on an electrochemical workstation (VMP3, Bio-Logic Science Instruments, France).
Water samples were withdrawn from the serum bottles at predetermined time intervals and then passed through 0.22 μm filters for further analysis. Both NB and AN were identified and quantified by high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC, LC-20, Shimadzu, Japan) equipped with an RP18 column (5 μm, 250 × 4.6 mm). The mobile phase ofwater–methanol (3/7, v/v)was set toflow at 1.0mLmin−1 and the injection volume was set at 10 μL. All analyses were conducted in triplicate and the data were reported as the arithmetic mean± standard deviation. NB removal efficiency and AN formation efficiencywere determined according to Luo et al. (2019). NB removal efficiency (RENB) and AN formation efficiency (FEAN) were calculated from the following equations:
RENB ¼ C0−CNBC0 100% ð1Þ
FEAN ¼ CANC0−CNB 100% ð2Þ
where C0 and CNB are NB concentrations (mM) in themedium at the beginning and the end of cycle, respectively; CAN is AN concentrations (mM) in the medium at the end of cycle.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
3.1. Characterization of modified BC
Themorphologies of the BC, H2O2-BC, NaOH-BC and HCl-BC samples were characterized by SEM (Fig. 1). As shown in Fig. 1a, the appearance of raw BCwas akin to that of a small hive with a porous shape. After oxidation modification, the surface of BC was visibly blocked; limited pores were observed (Fig. 1b). A similar phenomenon was observed by Wang et al. (2017), where the surface area and pore volume of pristine BC decreased after oxidation by H2O2. After treatment with NaOH, cracks were observed on the surface of NaOH-BC (Fig. 1c). The micropore walls of BC would be destroyed by NaOH, resulting in a decrease in total surface area (Stavropoulos et al., 2008). In contrast, more homogeneous micropores were observed on HCl-BC after HCl modification (Fig. 1d). Lignocellulosic, aliphatic and aromatic materials in BC could be destroyed by acid treatment to avoid shrinkage or contraction during the development of porosity (Liou and Wu, 2009). The results of the SEM show that the surface area of HCl-BC was higher than those of NaOH-BC and H2O2-BC, consistent with the BET surface area. As shown in Table S1, the BET surface area followed the order: HCl-BC N NaOH-BC N BC N H2O2-BC, showing a positive correlation with pore volume and a negative correlation with pore size.
The phase composition of BC andmodified BCwas evaluated by XRD characterization, as shown in Fig. S1. All BC samples showed identical spectra with broad diffraction peaks at 2θ of 20–30°, which could be attributed to the amorphous carbon structure having randomly oriented carbon sheets (Keiluweit et al., 2010). The relatively high XRD intensity of HCl-BC indicated the increase in crystallinity after HCl pretreatment, which could be attributed to the leaching of amorphous components in the presence of HCl (Binod et al., 2012). This result was similar to the
2-BC (b), NaOH-BC (c) and HCl-BC (d).
findings of Dong et al. (2018), where the crystallinity of raw BC became more pronounced after modification by HCl. As per the FTIR spectra (Fig. 2a), only a slight change in the chemical bonds on the BC surface was observed after modification, which could be attributed to the dominance of graphite C on the BC surface (Regmi et al., 2012). Compared with other modified BC, HCl-BC showed slightly higher adsorption at 1560 cm−1 and 1050 cm−1, whichwas attributed to C_O stretching vibrations (Li et al., 2017a). The results suggested a relatively high abundance of carbonyl groups on HCl-BC, which could be beneficial for electron transfer (Xu et al., 2019b). The peak at approximately 1388 cm−1, assigned to the –COOH stretching vibrations (Yang et al., 2018),was also enhanced after HCl pretreatment. Xue et al. (2012) indicated that –COOH on the BC surface played an important role in adsorption ofmetals through complexation. Therefore, it could be inferred that the interaction between –COOH and Fe2+ species could be improved, resulting in enhanced loading of S-nZVI after reduction by NaBH4. In addition, the electron donating capacity of BC might be increased due to the presence of –COOH, thus facilitating the electron exchange (Zhao and Zhou, 2019). The zeta potential of all the BC samples remained negative and decreased with the increase in pH from 5.0 to 11.0 (Fig. 2b). However, compared to BC treated by H2O2 and NaOH, BC treated by HCl showed a much higher negative charge, which indicated strong affinity for Fe2+ due to electrostatic attraction and surface precipitation (Xu et al., 2019a).
3.2. NB removal by S-nZVI supported on modified BC
As shown in Fig. 3a, 200 mg L−1 of NB could be completely removed by S-nZVI@HCl-BC within a reaction time as short as 60 min. However, NB removal efficiencies by S-nZVI@BC, S-nZVI@ H2O2-BC and S-nZVI@NaOH-BC within 60 min were 62.0 ± 4.5%, 35.2 ± 2.4% and 92.1 ± 4.2%, respectively, which were obviously lower than that of S-nZVI@HCl-BC. Sixty minutes later, NB removal efficiencies in all degradation systems remained stable until a reaction time of 120 min. Correspondingly, AN formation efficiency in the S-nZVI@HCl-BC degradation system increased rapidly to 86.7 ± 6.4% within 60min. For the degradation systems with the addition of S-nZVI@BC, S-nZVI@H2O2-BC and S-nZVI@NaOH-BC, AN formation efficiencies increased to 16.3 ± 6.2%, 6.5 ± 1.2% and 70.4 ± 4.3% within 60 min, respectively, which were also obviously lower than that of the S-nZVI@HCl-BC degradation system (Fig. 3b). In general, both NB removal and AN formation efficiencies followed the order: S-nZVI@HCl-BC N S-nZVI@NaOH-BC N S-nZVI@BC N S-nZVI@ H2O2-BC. The rather high NB removal and AN formation efficiency observed in the degradation system with the addition of S-nZVI@ HCl-BC indicated that the reduction performance of S-nZVI@BC could be improved through acid modification of BC. Nevertheless, in the systems with added BC, H2O2-BC, NaOH-BC and HCl-BC, less

than 10% of 200mg L−1 of NBwas removed and ANwas undetectable within 120 min. This result suggested that NB removal through adsorption or reduction by BC or modified BC was insignificant, confirming the key role of S-nZVI in both NB removal and AN formation. The major pathway of chemical reduction of NB was proposed to include three steps with AN as the end product, and with nitrosobenzene and hydroxylaminobenzene as the intermediates (Liang et al., 2013). According to the previous studies, NB could be easily reduced by direct electron donation of nZVI, ferrous ions and FeS (Liang et al., 2013; Yu et al., 2011; Dong et al., 2017b). Moreover, enhanced electron transfer between S-nZVI@BC and the adsorbed NB facilitated NB reduction, considering the excellent electron conductivity of FeS and the electron transfer capacity of BC (Li et al., 2016; Oh et al., 2015).
From the above results, it could be inferred that pretreatment of BC by acid before the loading of S-nZVI was beneficial for both NB removal and AN formation. Since reduction of NB to AN is proposed to include three steps, with 6 mol of electrons involved for each mol of NB, it was intuitive that the electron transfer efficiency between S-nZVI and NB is rather crucial for NB reduction (Chen et al., 2014). As shown in Fig. 4a, the redox peak of a glassy carbon electrode (GCE) modified by S-nZVI@HCl-BC had a higher current density than that of a GCE modified by other composites (Zheng et al., 2009). Furthermore, Nyquist plots (Fig. 4b) showed that the S-nZVI@HCl-BC modified GCE had a smaller semicircle diameter but lower Z″ value at high frequency than the GCE modified by the other composites. These results indicated that S-nZVI@HCl-BC had better electron transfer efficiency than SnZVI@H2O2-BC and S-nZVI@NaOH-BC, which could be attributed to acid modification of BC (Turcio-Ortega et al., 2012).
On the other hand, the loading of S-nZVI onto BC could be affected by the surface properties of BC. As indicated in Fig. 5a, defined and discrete S-nZVI particles could be observed on the surface and in the channels of S-nZVI@BC. The loading of S-nZVI on H2O2-BC was quite limited probably due to the blocked pores (Fig. 5b). However, it was worth noting that S-nZVI bloomed on the surface of both NaOH-BC (Fig. 5c) and HCl-BC (Fig. 5d), especially for HCl-BC, probably due to the larger surface area, more negative surface charge and increased acidic functional groups on HCl-BC. XRD spectra also confirmed the difference in the loading of S-nZVI on modified BC or raw BC, as indicated in Fig. S2. The XRD peak at 2θ of 44.64° was more pronounced for S-nZVI@HCl-BC than other BC supported SnZVI, confirming the highest abundance of S-nZVI loaded onto HClBC as compared to other modified BC or raw BC.

sections.heading: 3.3. Effect of S-nZVI/BC mass ratio on NB removal
sections.text:
Based on the above discussion, it could be concluded that S-nZVI@ HCl-BC performed the best in terms of NB removal. Therefore, SnZVI@HCl-BC was chosen for further investigation to reveal the effect of mass ratio of S-nZVI and HCl-BC on NB removal (Fig. 6). As the mass ratio of S-nZVI/HCl-BC increased from 0.5:1 to 3:1, NB removal efficiency and AN formation efficiency within 60 min increased from 59.3 ±2.3% and 41.9±3.2% to 100% and 84.7±3.1%, respectively. However, as themass ratio further increased to 7:1, NB removal efficiency and AN formation efficiencywithin 60min decreased to 36.2±1.2% and 20.2± 3.8%, respectively, much lower than that in the case of the 3:1 ratio. These results indicated that the optimal mass ratio of S-nZVI/HCl-BC was 3:1 in this study.
SEM analysis was carried out in order to explore the effect of the SnZVI/HCl-BC mass ratio on the distribution of S-nZVI onto the HCl-BC surface. Fig. S3 shows that S-nZVI was distributed uniformly onto the HCl-BC surface at the S-nZVI/HCl-BC ratio of 3:1. However, sparsely distributed S-nZVI was formed when the mass ratio of S-nZVI/HCl-BC was controlled at 0.5:1 and1:1. Obvious aggregation of S-nZVI on the surface of HCl-BCwas observed at the S-nZVI/HCl-BCmass ratios of 5:1 and 7:1. The reactivity of S-nZVI@HCl-BC for NB removal could be decreased in case of excessive loading of HCl-BC, which could be attributed to the accelerated formation of oxide shells on S-nZVI at excessive loading of HCl-BC (Zhu et al., 2018). Lai et al. (2013) also indicated that the removal efficiency of 3,3′-iminobis-propanenitrile in a micro-electrolysis system decreased at excessive granular activated carbon loading, which acted as the cathodes of the macroscopic galvanic cells, promoting electron transfer. In this study, S-nZVI particles distributed evenly onto HCl-BC at a mass ratio of 3:1, providing more reactive sites for NB removal and AN formation. The relatively low reactivity of S-nZVI/ HCl-BC at high mass ratios of 5:1 and 7:1 could be attributed to the obvious aggregation of the S-nZVI particles. Further, at a high mass ratio, incorporation of S-nZVI into the inner channel or pores of HCl-BC would reduce the reactive sites for NB removal and AN formation.

sections.heading: 3.4. Possible mechanisms involved in enhanced NB removal by SnZVI@HCl-BC
sections.text:
Enhanced NB reduction was obtained by S-nZVI@HCl-BC as compared to S-nZVI@BC, S-nZVI@H2O2-BC and S-nZVI@NaOH-BC, indicating the relevance of NB reduction to biochar properties. Based on SEM, XRD, FTIR, zeta potential and electrochemical analysis, it could be inferred
that mechanisms such as elevated electron transfer and increased loading of S-nZVI could be involved in the enhanced reducibility of S-nZVI@ HCl-BC, as indicated in Fig. 7. On the one hand, the elevated electron transfer efficiency between S-nZVI and NB was achieved with more C_O and –COOHgroups onHCl-BC, whichwas rather crucial for the enhancement of NB reduction by S-nZVI@HCl-BC. On the other hand, the enhanced NB reduction of S-nZVI@HCl-BC might be attributed to the fact that the surface property of HCl-BC was more suitable for loading of S-nZVI. Various processes such as adsorption, electrostatic attraction, surface complexation and metal-π interaction could be involved in the loading of S-nZVI onto HCl-BC. Larger surface area of HCl-BC provided

more potential adsorption sites for Fe2+, which was beneficial for the loading of S-nZVI onto BC. Moreover, HCl-BC was more negatively charged as compared to BC pretreated by H2O2 and NaOH. The electrostatic attraction between HCl-BC and Fe2+ could be enhanced, resulting in more uniform distribution of S-nZVI onto HCl-BC. The abundant – COOH groups on the surface of HCl-BC had a strong affinity for Fe2+ due to surface complexation, which had positive effect on the even distribution of S-nZVI. Harvey et al. (2011) demonstrated that the aromatic structure of BC and functional groups such as C_C could interact with metals by metal–π interaction. Thus, Fe2+–π interaction in HCl-BC could be enhanced, making S-nZVI deposition easier and quicker.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In the present study, the pretreatment of BC by HCl was found to be an effective method for the enhancement of NB reduction by S-nZVI@ BC. NB removal and AN formation of S-nZVI@HCl-BC could be significantly enhanced as compared with S-nZVI@NaOH-BC and S-nZVI@ H2O2-BC. The mass ratio of S-nZVI and HCl-BC was optimized at 3:1 in terms of NB removal and AN formation. Elevated electron transfer and enhanced loading of S-nZVI were responsible for enhanced NB removal by S-nZVI@HCl-BC. Considering the simplicity and cost-effectiveness of HCl pretreatment, S-nZVI@HCl-BC could be a promising remediation material for efficient NB removal.

referenceMentions.context: Nitrobenzene (NB) has been extensively used in the production of explosives, insecticides, pharmaceuticals and dyes, resulting in increasing environmental deterioration caused by NB pollution (Mu et al., 2009).
The suggested maximum allowable concentrations in wastewater and drinking water are 1 mg L and 17 μg L, respectively (Zhang and Chen, 2009).
Therefore, the control of NB pollution has gained increasing attention (Dong et al., 2015).

Reductive degradation, either biotic or abiotic, is more favorable than oxidative degradation due to the electron-deficient character of the nitro group in NB (Zhang et al., 2007).

The primary reduction product of NB, that is, aniline (AN), is much less toxic and much more biodegradable than NB, suggesting the effectiveness of reductive degradation in terms of detoxification (Paula et al., 2015).

Recently, the potential role of sulfidated nano zerovalent iron (SnZVI) in pollutant remediation has attracted significant attention due to its larger specific surface area and higher reduction capacity than nZVI (Han and Yan, 2016).
The generated iron sulfide can act as an electron transfer medium, which can efficiently transfer electrons from the nZVI core to target pollutants on its surface (Tang et al., 2016).
However, the application of S-nZVI in the field of environmental remediation still poses some challenges, such as easy agglomeration, easy oxidation and extra electron loss (Zhang et al., 2018).
Loading of nZVI onto support materials such as biopolymers, minerals and carbonaceous material has been widely investigated to prevent the aggregation and oxidation of nZVI (Stefaniuk et al., 2016).
In our previous study, biochar (BC) supported S-nZVI (S-nZVI@BC) was successfully prepared through simultaneous reduction of FeSO4 by Na2S2O4 and NaBH4 onto BC (Zhang et al., 2018).

BC, which can be easily produced from cost-optimal raw biomass by pyrolysis under limited oxygen conditions, is attracting increasing attention in the field of environmental remediation (Chen et al., 2014).
Nevertheless, on account of the limited porosity and functional groups, pristine BC shows poor performance in contaminant removal (Tang et al., 2018).
Therefore, appropriate modification of BC is necessary to improve remediation efficiency and ensure environmental benefits (Rajapaksha et al., 2016; Liu et al., 2015).
